questions.question: What did Loftus and Palmer (1974) find regarding the impact of leading questions on eyewitness testimony?
options: Participants estimated higher speeds with the word 'smashed'
Participants recalled more details with the word 'contacted'
Participants were less confident with leading questions
Participants showed no difference in speed estimates
questions.explanation: Loftus and Palmer found that the wording of leading questions significantly influenced participants' speed estimates, with 'smashed' leading to higher estimates. This corresponds to: Participants estimated higher speeds with the word 'smashed'.

questions.question: In a study on eyewitness testimony, participants who were asked if they saw broken glass after being exposed to a car crash video were influenced by which factor?
options: The clarity of the video
The type of question asked
The time elapsed since the event
The number of witnesses present
questions.explanation: The type of question asked influenced participants' recollection, demonstrating how leading questions can alter memory

questions.question: How can post-event discussion affect eyewitness testimony?
options: It enhances memory recall
It can contaminate a witness's memory
It has no effect on memory
It improves the accuracy of details
questions.explanation: Post-event discussion can lead to the incorporation of misleading information, contaminating the eyewitness's original memory. This corresponds to: It can contaminate a witness's memory.

questions.question: What is one methodological issue with Loftus and Palmer's (1974) study on leading questions?
options: Participants were not matched for age
The study lacked ecological validity
The sample size was too small
Participants were not debriefed
questions.explanation: The study used a video of a car crash, which may not evoke the same emotional response as witnessing a real accident, affecting ecological validity. This corresponds to: The study lacked ecological validity.

questions.question: What is the cognitive interview designed to improve?
options: The reliability of eyewitness testimony
The speed of police interviews
The number of witnesses interviewed
The accuracy of police reports
questions.explanation: The cognitive interview is specifically designed to enhance the reliability and accuracy of eyewitness testimony. This corresponds to: The reliability of eyewitness testimony.

questions.question: Which technique is NOT part of the cognitive interview?
options: Changing perspective
Report everything
Leading questions
Reinstating the context
questions.explanation: Leading questions are not part of the cognitive interview; instead, techniques aim to facilitate accurate recall

questions.question: In the context of eyewitness testimony, what does the term 'misleading information' refer to?
options: Accurate details provided by witnesses
Information that alters a witness's memory
The original memory of the event
The emotional state of the witness
questions.explanation: Misleading information refers to details that can distort a witness's memory of the event. This corresponds to: Information that alters a witness's memory.

questions.question: What was a key finding from the research on anxiety and eyewitness testimony?
options: Anxiety always improves memory recall
Anxiety has no effect on memory
High anxiety can impair memory accuracy
Anxiety only affects childrenâ€™s memory
questions.explanation: Research indicates that high levels of anxiety can negatively impact the accuracy of eyewitness memory. This corresponds to: High anxiety can impair memory accuracy.

questions.question: What is one criticism of the cognitive interview technique?
options: It is too time-consuming
It is not based on psychological research
It increases the number of false memories
It is only effective for children
questions.explanation: One criticism of the cognitive interview is that it can be time-consuming, which may limit its practicality in real-world situations. This corresponds to: It is too time-consuming.

questions.question: How does the Innocence Project highlight the importance of accurate eyewitness testimony?
options: By claiming that 50% of convictions are based on eyewitness testimony
By showing that 72% of DNA exonerations involved inaccurate eyewitness testimony
By stating that eyewitness testimony is always reliable
By emphasizing the role of leading questions in trials
questions.explanation: The Innocence Project claims that a significant percentage of wrongful convictions overturned by DNA testing involved inaccurate eyewitness testimony. This corresponds to: By showing that 72% of DNA exonerations involved inaccurate eyewitness testimony.
